I can find nothing in the writings of men like Aristotle or Locke or Hobbes, to name a few examples, which support a natural law right of smoking marijuana (admittedly, however, I did not consider the writings of Timothy Leary nor did I review the ill fated presidential campaign of George McGovern). 
 
 I have looked for support for a marijuana civil liberty interest in the wording of my constitution, where I have found a recognized RKBA. But I can find no amendment numbered 2.1 which reads "the right of the people to grow and use marijuana shall not be infringed." 
 
 Having failed to find a civil liberty of drug use in these locations, I turned at last to the "penumbra" doctrine and the theory of "substantive due process," which says some rights not stated in the Constitution are still protected by its reach (abortion being the most recognized example found by SCOTUS). This theory was best described in a former minority opinion quote which has gained favor with more than one current SCOTUS justice: 
 
 "[T]he full scope of the liberty guaranteed by the Due Process Clause cannot be found in or limited by the precise terms of the specific guarantees elsewhere provided in the Constitution. This "liberty" is not a series of isolated points pricked out in terms of the taking of property; the freedom of speech, press, and religion; the right to keep and bear arms; the freedom from unreasonable searches and seizures; and so on. It is a rational continuum which, broadly speaking, includes a freedom from all substantial arbitrary impositions and purposeless restraints, . . . and which also recognizes, what a reasonable and sensitive judgment must, that certain interests require particularly careful scrutiny of the state needs asserted to justify their abridgment. Poe v. Ullman, supra, 367 U.S., at 543." (Justice Stevens used this quote in his dissent in Albright v. Oliver, 510 U.S.266 (1994), which involved a civil lawsuit brought by Albright under a claim he had been denied "due process" of law when he was charged and arrested for a crime without a finding of probable cause that he had committed the crime. Justice O'Conner (now retired) used this quote in her majority opinion in the abortion rights case of PLANNED PARENTHOOD OF SE PA. v. CASEY, 505 U.S. 833, 6 (1992), which was joined with approval by current Justices Kennedy and Souter.) 
 
 I can find no support for the argument that the activities of smoking marijuana or crack or injecting heroin would fall within the "rational continuum" of unexpressed but protected due process clause liberty interests.
